title: World News: World Watch
text:
Other Activists

A trial began Monday for Hong Kong media tycoon Jimmy Lai and seven other pro-democracy activists charged over their roles in an unauthorized Tiananmen vigil last year, amid a crackdown on political dissent in Hong Kong.

Mr. Lai and the others face charges that include organizing, participating and inciting others to take part in the unauthorized vigil commemorating the deadly 1989 crackdown on protesters in Beijing's Tiananmen Square.

Mr. Lai, the founder of the now-defunct pro-democracy newspaper Apple Daily, pleaded not guilty to inciting others to take part in the unauthorized assembly.

-- Associated Press

ETHIOPIA

Leader Is Defiant

As Rebels Advance

Ethiopia's prime minister called on citizens to redouble their efforts to combat the rival Tigray forces who claim to have seized key cities on a major highway leading to the capital, while a new wave of detentions of ethnic Tigrayans has begun.

A move on the Ethiopian capital of Addis Ababa is a new phase in the war that has killed thousands of people since fighting broke out a year ago between Ethiopian and allied forces and Tigray ones who long dominated the national government before Prime Minister Abiy Ahmed took office in 2018.

The prime minister's spokeswoman, Billene Seyoum, said Monday that Mr. Abiy "is where he's meant to be, leading the country's front and center."

Mr. Abiy said Sunday that federal troops are fighting on four fronts against the Tigray forces and "we should know that our enemy's main strength is our weakness and unpreparedness."

Amid calls on social media for attacks against ethnic Tigrayans, he said "we should closely follow those who work for the enemy and live amongst us." A new roundup of Tigrayans was seen in the capital on Monday.

The Tigray forces say they are pressuring Ethiopia's government to lift a monthslong blockade on their region of around six million people.

-- Associated Press

WEST BANK

Israel Authorizes

Palestinian Homes

Israel authorized some 1,300 Palestinian homes in the occupied West Bank on Monday, days after advancing plans to build more than 3,000 housing units for Jewish settlers.

The Israeli government says it is adopting a moderate approach with the aim of minimizing friction with the U.S. -- which is opposed to settlements -- and tensions within its ruling coalition, which includes parties from across the political spectrum.

The Palestinians and rights groups say the newly authorized homes meet only a fraction of the need in the 60% of the West Bank that is under full Israeli control. Military permits for Palestinian construction are rarely granted and unauthorized structures often are demolished.

An Israeli security official confirmed the approval of the Palestinian housing, saying it authorized existing homes and gave permission to build new ones, without providing a breakdown.

Israel captured the West Bank in the 1967 Mideast war, and the Palestinians want it to form the main part of their future state.

-- Associated Press

U.K.-FRANCE

Fishing Talks Held

As Deadline Looms

French and British officials met Monday to talk about fishing, as the deadline for a threatened French blockade of British boats and trucks approached.

The European Commission said it had called a meeting involving officials from Britain, France and the Channel Islands of Jersey and Guernsey, which are self-governing British Crown dependencies with control over their own territorial waters.

France has threatened to bar British boats from some of its ports and tighten checks on boats and trucks carrying British goods if more French vessels aren't licensed to fish in U.K. waters by Tuesday. The French president's office said Monday that the port blockade would begin at midnight if no compromise is found.

The U.K. played down the significance of Monday's meeting, saying it was "part of the ongoing, continuing discussions that have been going on for months now."

Both sides have accused each other of contravening the Brexit trade deal that the U.K. signed when it left the EU.

-- Associated Press
